text: Hi emma, sorry for the delayed response. Been spending the past week preparing for the interview tomorrow afternoon.
I like the attention to detail and persistence that is required of you in VFX, I find that exciting. Similar to lab work I had to do for my degree.

I'd consider myself a sociable person, I work well with other people and am more than capable of working my own too. As for spending time in a VFX studio or film sent I haven't, getting work experience on film sets or any VFX studio has proved tricky for me so far, as most places tend to want someone with experience but I have none as I'm just starting out so it's almost like walking around in a circle.
Closest I've been to that is spending time at The Farm (london and manchester) and LipSync in London.
Not sure what you mean by the last part of your message regarding broadcasting though

I would say that you need to get that license set up in Nuke and start playing as soon as you can!!   Broadcast: I meant that in lots of Natural History and documentarys they have a member of team on board that knows about the science... so you may be able to use the degree that you already have.

attachments.title: So you want to be a TV researcher?
attachments.text: Researchers are common to all genres of TV production, and every ambitious production runner wants to become one. The name seems self-explanatory. But what do those scary additional words, like 'shooting' or 'casting' actually mean? Our expert interviewees help you work out what kind of researcher you want to be, and how you get there.
attachments.fallback: Royal Television Society: So you want to be a TV researcher?
